Steps to configure the Azure CSPM audit. Steps Leave your Azure portal page open as we will need information from here in Step 3 below. Open a new window or tab and login to the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE admin portal, then navigate to the Protect > Policies page and select Microsoft 365 to open the application settings page. Then select Setup API. Next select the checkbox for Audit Azure Configuration and then click the green plus icon to add a new instance you want to audit. In the Add Azure Instance dialog enter a name you want to give that particular instance (can be anything you want to use to identify it) and then go back to your prior tab/window with the Azure portal open. Click on App Services in the left column and then click on the particular Azure instance you want to audit. In the new page locate the Azure Subscription ID and copy that and paste that into the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Azure Subscription ID field. Click OK when you are done. You will see your instance added to the table with a blank status field. Click Save in the top right corner. You will then see the status change to a yellow exclamation icon. Click on the icon and you will see a link to authorize the API connection (again remember to use an admin or owner account for the Azure instance you are trying to audit). Once you authorize you will see the icon change to a green checkmark indicating a successful connection. Once the setup is completed the first audit scan will kick o

For IP and Device Cutoff Methods please view the Microsoft Exchange cutoff prohibits users from connecting to your Exchange server directly via ActiveSync, ensuring that all mobile devices connect through Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. It works in stages:

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE allows you to control login policies across all apps integrated with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as well as access to the admin portal.

The Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Admin Portal tile allows you to manage user or group access to the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Admin Portal itself. You can access the Admin Portal tile under the Protect > Policies page.

The Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Login Policy allows admins to apply global login policies to their users across all protected cloud applications contextually based on a number of variables such as user group, device, location and behavior.
You can delay a users login for a specified amount of time based on the context and behavior (failing login attempts).
You can block users logins to applications entirely from risky locations or time based for contractors by not allowing access outside of work hours.
Administrator can enforce an Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) check after a user authentication before granting access.
Administrator can configure expire session login policy to force the user to re-authenticate a session after a certain period of inactivity.
The Common Objects page is where you can define some of the objects that will be used on the policies page for controlling and performing actions in protected applications.
The Custom Notification Files are used when configuring a cloud policy to quarantine files when matching based on a condition. This file will replace the original file that is quarantined.

The Custom Locations page located under Protect > Objects is where you can define custom locations that can be used on the policies page for controlling and performing actions in protected applications.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides three methods to distinguish between managed and unmanaged devices. This allows for greater restrictions to be applied to users using unmanaged devices.
Customers can upload a Root CA certificate that will be used to validate if a client cert presented by a user during the SAML 2.0 authentication process is legitimate.

The Device Profiles section available under Protect > Objects > Common Objects page works in conjunction with the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE SmartEdge agent to determine if your device is managed or unmanaged.
You can create device profiles to determine managed devices when creating policies and providing different levels of access on managed and unmanaged devices.
Admins can configure SAML attributes to be passed from the external IdP to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE to determine if a device is managed or unmanaged.
The SmartEdge Agent can be installed on either Windows or Mac devices and will profile the machines for attributes defined on the Protect > Objects > Device Profile Objects .

Once you have determined the means through which you will determine a managed device, you can move on to creating policies to provide greater access to managed devices while restricting access to unmanaged devices.

DLP is a data loss prevention capability that allows for pattern matching (via regular expressions and keywords) against data as it is either being downloaded, uploaded, or scanned via API at rest.

You need to upload the JSON file provided with your Forcepoint order confirmation mail as part of the on-boarding process or requested from Forcepoint Technical Support. This is to ensure that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can interact with the DPS configured on the FSM and implement policies configured on the FSM.

After uploading and validating DPS license JSON, you can select Forcepoint DLP data pattern from the Data Patterns section while configuring API scanning of files for any of the following supported ...
Describes the list of applications against DPS actions supported.

The Settings > DLP page enables you to specify quarantine and create copy locations that will be used when FSM returns an API policy action indicating a quarantine or create copy. These are global ...
A new predefined data pattern named Forcepoint DLP is available under Protect > Objects > DLP Objects page.

You can integrate Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | DLP so that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can enforce DLP policy and associated actions setup in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | DLP for CASB channel in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.

You can integrate Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | DLP so that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can enforce DLP policy and associated actions setup in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | DLP for SWG channel in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.
are those data patterns which are already available in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE and can be used while configuring policies.

Once predefined file type based DLP patterns are enabled on your tenant, the DLP Objects page displays three predefined DLP patterns for standard file types which can be used while configuring inline (ZTNA and CASB), SWG content and API policies to detect or block content based on file types.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE contains a large number of predefined DLP patterns based on commonly used objects including matching patterns for Credit Cards, sensitive keywords, U.S. Social Security Numbers, and more.

Advanced DLP Pattern Objects allow you to form more complicated patterns that use several primitives combined into expressions using boolean logic, including weighted counts of the number of matches found for specified DLP patterns.

At times you might want to create a policy that, when violated, will assign users to a risky group to restrict further access and allow admins to review their activity before removing them from the risk group. You can accomplish this using Advanced Patterns and the AssignToGroup construct.

Use the ContentTypeHexRe("<hexlified regex string>") in advanced pattern to match if the content type (mime type) of the file matches to the specified regex. The ContentTypeHexRe("<hexlified regex string>") accepts a hex encoded form of regular expression for mime types.

Use the FileNameHexRe("<hexlified regex string>") in advanced pattern to match the file name with the specified regex. The FileNameHexRe("<hexlified regex string>") accepts a hex encoded form of regular expression for file name.

Allows you to upload a tokenized csv file to scan through your data-at-rest looking for exact matches based on the data in the uploaded file. You can create an Exact Match pattern in a similar way to creating a Simple or Advanced pattern.
The File Fingerprinting type allows you to create a fingerprint based on a doc or a number of docs to perform a percentage-based match.
File Mime Type allows you to create a pattern looking at the mime type (the format of the file itself) rather than based on the content inside of the file.

Admins can also choose to control files based on their size. This will allow admins to ensure that users are not downloading large files or preventing large files from being uploaded to their sanctioned cloud storage application.
The File Metadata data pattern type allows you to specify the exact inherent metadata and value you wish to match on.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides Advanced Threat Protection (ATP) via partnerships with an antimalware provider.

You can protect your cloud application from malware by setting up ATP scanning using any of the ATP options that you have purchased. Setting up ATP scanning for your cloud application, is same as configuring any other data pattern with minor difference.
Describes the various types of file formats that are supported for scanning.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE supports inline DLP scanning, and API (Cloud) scanning.
Lists supported file MIME Types for both access and API scanning.
Lists additional file MIME Types supported specifically for API scanning.
Field Programmable SASE Logic (FPSL) provides unprecedented support for inline controls over user action and activities within cloud services.
As FPSL utilizes Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE's native DLP engine, you will need to configure FPSL in DLP Data Patterns and added to Upload policies in each app you wish to control.
To get started, you will first need to know what inputs are supported for creating the advanced pattern code.

Once you have the above input information that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE uses in the code, you now need to figure out the request information in order to tell the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE system what to block.
When crafting Lua code, it is recommended to create Lua code in a code or text editor such as Notepad++ to make it easier to format, read, and edit.

This topic describes how to create and utilize combined patterns, that is combining multiple actions. For example, if you want to just identify twitter posts and then apply inline DLP, then would need to create two different patterns.
Following are some examples of FPSL patterns that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE have created that you can either use in your own tenants or that you can use a template for creating your own.
Simple patterns allow you to set specific keyword triggers, create regular expressions, or use special keywords to match custom properties.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE enables you to capture 20 characters that immediately precede and follow the sensitive content match in a file.
Expressions in simple data patterns can be build using different operators.

When using the SmartEdge agent or Cloud-SWG to provide controls over sites/applications based on application categories or trustworthiness, admins can create their own group of specific domains to apply policy to.
This topic describes how to add custom URL category object.
You can import custom categories in bulk in csv format.
The External IdP card is where you can add any external IdP to be used for authentication within your domain or by individual app or app instances.
Admins can now identify and control users performing bulk activities, such as modifying, downloading, deleting and sharingchanging of files, for data at rest.
To enable offline scanning of cloud applications, configure an API connection to one or more of your selected cloud applications. Then configure data at rest and API-based enforcement policy actions.
After you have setup the API, you can choose specific settings for what is getting scanned. This can be specific folders or even users. Setting options may differ based on the application.
Selective scanning settings are the same for Box and Dropbox.
Customers can setup selective scanning for Microsoft 365 to gain visibility into data in OneDrive, SharePoint, and Calendar/Emails.
For Google Workspace, admins can setup scanning for visibility into data in GDrive, Calendar and Email messages, and Google Cloud Platform.
Each application can have multiple cloud policy rules which are evaluated in a top down fashion until a match is found. All rule criteria must match for the actions to be applied.
The configured action takes place when an API scan matches the conditions. Actions include Allow, Quarantine, Create Copy, Remove Share, and Encrypt (for Microsoft 365 only).
Quarantined files can be viewed on the Analyze > Logs > API page by adding the filter Column:Action = Quarantined.
In addition to triggered cloud policy actions, Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides the ability for admins to apply manual cloud actions to files through the API Logs.

The Condition clause forms the API policy. The possible match criteria for the condition are as follows: User Groups: All users scanned by the API as defined in the Selective Scanning settings or locally defined groups or security groups and OUs pulled from active directory Status: The current status of the file. DLP: If the file contents match a DLP pattern. External: If the file has been shared with a person with a domain outside of the domains listed on the IAM > Users and Groups page (a domain that isn't configured inside of your Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE tenant). Internal: If the file has been shared with a person with a domain that exists on the IAM > Users and Groups. Public: If the file was shared by a Public link that anyone can access without authentication. Shared: If the file is shared in any manner including all options above (External, Internal, public). File Name: Match by the exact file name. File size: Match files based on it's file size, can be less than (or equal to) greather than (or equal to) a specified size in bytes. Owner: The user who is the owner of the file. Shared With: The user with whom the file is shared (applicable in case when the file is shared externally or internally) Data Pattern: The particular pattern that is matched against the file contents.These are the patterns that you have included under the API Setup page for the application. Actor: Indicates the performer who modified, deleted, sharingchanged, moved, renamed or downloa
For Google Workspace and Microsoft 365, you can scan emails and calendar for visibility into sensitive content (both text within the subject/body or attachments).

Sensitive data often exists in image-based formats, such as scanned documents and PDFs. Optical Character Recognition (OCR) API scanning in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE automatically extracts and inspects text from these files, ensuring that embedded content is protected by the same data security policies as standard text-based files.

This is where you will manage all of your protected applications. This page will walk you through the basics of the Protect > Policies and act as a landing page to link you to the relevant pages to walk you through configuring your application policies.

Each application can have multiple policy rules which are evaluated in a top down fashion until a match is found. All rule criteria must match for the actions to be applied. An implied deny rule is ...
The final column under each app titled Actions allows you to apply DLP policy actions via secure app access, grant direct app access, isolate (only for SWG Content Policy) or deny access to the app.

For cloud applications that are supported over the ActiveSync Proxy (Google, O365), there is an extra column under Download DLP to control sensitive data inside of the subject line or body of the email over ActiveSync.

All managed cloud applications as well as custom applications support download DLP action for files. Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE will process files as they are downloaded to look for the DLP pattern you have configured in your policy and then apply the appropriate action.
Most managed applications will support DLP actions on upload of files.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can block unwanted upload attempts but make exceptions after a user supplies justification.
Once you have created your notification, you can now attach the notification to your policy.

Every application includes options of whether or not to enable file watermarking (on download or upload actions) which allows you to track user usage of Microsoft Office docs (DOCX, PPTX, XLSX) and PDFs.
When applying a download encrypt DLP policy on file(s), the file(s) are encrypted upon download and requires users to provide a password to access the files. The password used is unique to each user.
Allows O365 users to preview PDF documents while blocking the download and saving of local copies on any device.
When using the SWG, customers can also configure policies to send over HTTP request headers during authentication to apply more granular controls within the application itself.

At times you may encounter applications that set cookies on direct request that prevents or breaks a login attempt to an application with users being sent through the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE reverse proxy.

The Forcepoint Remote Browser Isolation (Forcepoint RBI) functionality is available based on a separate license. You should reach out to your Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE representative or support team to opt for separate license and to activate the RBI functionality on your tenant. Once enabled, you should see the Isolate option on the SWG Content Policy's Actions dialog.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can apply the create copy action via an Advanced Data Pattern.
At times you may want to encrypt certain objects or attributes in an application while users input data inline or when passing an API call to an external endpoint.
Field level encryption in any app requires a couple of different components to be setup within your Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE tenant.

Steps for creating the code block. Steps Start by logging into the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE admin portal and navigating to Protect > Encryption > Key Management. Click the green plus icon under the Code Books card to create a new code book. On the Code Book dialog: Enter a recognizable name. Select the key vault that you created previously that you wish to use. Select default for the Storage Region. To create a code block with the entered details, click Create. Creating the Code Book Steps for creating the code block. Steps Start by logging into the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE admin portal and navigating to Protect > Encryption > Key Management. Click the green plus icon under the Code Books card to create a new code book. On the Code Book dialog: Enter a recognizable name. Select the key vault that you created previously that you wish to use. Select default for the Storage Region. To create a code block with the entered details, click Create. Steps for creating the code block. Steps Start by logging into the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE admin portal and navigating to Protect > Encryption > Key Management. Click the green plus icon under the Code Books card to create a new code book. On the Code Book dialog: Enter a recognizable name. Select the key vault that you created previously that you wish to use. Select default for the Storage Region. To create a code block with the entered details, click Create.

Steps for creating any API gateway. Steps Navigate to Protect > Add Apps > Managed Apps and select Any API from the list. On the API Proxy Configuration dialog: Enter a name for the application. Enter the URL endpoint you will be using to access the application. If you are using ServiceNow for example, the URL is https://dev95972.service-now.com. Select Connect to Custom App and then select the app you created from the dropdown as well as the app instance (if the custom app you created has more than one). Click OK and then click Save. Once done, you can now focus on setting up encryption or tokenization for the application. Setup will differ based on if you are planning to encrypt inline, via API, or both. Creating any API gateway Steps for creating any API gateway. Steps Navigate to Protect > Add Apps > Managed Apps and select Any API from the list. On the API Proxy Configuration dialog: Enter a name for the application. Enter the URL endpoint you will be using to access the application. If you are using ServiceNow for example, the URL is https://dev95972.service-now.com. Select Connect to Custom App and then select the app you created from the dropdown as well as the app instance (if the custom app you created has more than one). Click OK and then click Save. Once done, you can now focus on setting up encryption or tokenization for the application. Setup will differ based on if you are planning to encrypt inline, via API, or both. Steps for creating any API gateway. Steps N
With the Code Book created, you can now create a custom app that will hold the encryption setup.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides a number of available encryption/tokenization options depending on your current needs/requirements.
If you do not intend to perform inline encryption and only encrypt via API calls you can skip this section.
The API encryption and field mapping will instead be performed in the Any API app you added.

At times data that is encrypted by Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE in an app is moved to another app. Data will need to be decrypted before it is sent or else the new application will not be able to interpret the data.

Customers can configure groups of SaaS apps from our cloud app repository and export that information to ingest that information into third party SWG's for automated blocking. Currently, this feature supports Bluecoat (Broadcom) and PANW.

Admins can create custom notification objects that can be applied to policies and reports. This will determine which admins or users are notified when a policy is violated and what the custom message says.
Admins can create custom new inline notification so that it can used while creating a policy.
Admins can create custom user email notification so that it can used while creating a policy.
Admins can create custom group email notification so that it can used while creating a policy.

The Other Messages page allows admins to customize various messages that will display for users such as if they land on the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE login portal page or when triggering a policy action such as a blocked file or the watermark being applied to the file.
Use the Email Reports page to set up notifications that notify admins through email whenever specific system alerts are triggered.
While creating and updating notifications, you can insert (Message Personalization) variables to the body of the notifications.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE supports SmartEdge Agent and Cloud SWG traffic steering methods. This chapter describes steps to deploy each of those so that traffic can be forwarded to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE's SmartEdge endpoint agent provides Secure Web Gateway (SWG) controls on managed devices without the latency or overhead costs involved with backhauled cloud proxies or physical SWG boxes.

The SmartEdge agent downloads the configuration and then proxies all user traffic. Reputation and web/app category are looked up for the URL, then an appropriate web browsing policy is applied to the traffic. Traffic can be blocked, proxied to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE cloud servers for DLP, or allowed to go direct to the end application server. Aside from the portal page, the below domains, file paths, and registry entries need to be allowed for the Security tool and Antivirus exclusions.
Testing antivirus scanning exceptions for SmartEdge Agent using EICAR method.
The Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE SmartEdge agent is a discreet agent designed to work on most modern computers.
Lists the best practices for rolling SmartEdge Agents.

For customers using other endpoint management agents such as Carbon Black or FireEye, you may need to allow the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE SmartEdge agent installer, the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE signed certificate, as well as the services/processes it runs to ensure the installation and/or services are not blocked by your security controls.
For allowing the installer, it is best to locate the hash and add this to your systems allow list directly.
Allowing the services/processes and the Certificate can be done manually or by adding them once they are identified by the your endpoint system after the agent has been running on a machine.
You can either allow list the Bitglass certificate manually or automatically.
The SmartEdge agent can be downloaded from the Protect > Forward Proxy > SmartEdge Proxy page in the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE portal.

When selecting Managed App Traffic Only, admins will have the ability to input an external PAC file URL that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE will automatically use to merge with the PAC file that is generated based on your configured policy in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE and push that down to the device.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE's SmartEdge agent supports the ability to exclude or bypass specific sites or networks from being proxied through Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. This can be applied globally based on the traffic, private networks, or specific domain URLs.
The User Authentication option will allow admins to control how users are prompted to login to the agent for applying policy controls.

Admins can control if users with admin access on their machines are able to uninstall the SmartEdge Proxy agent. This control can be applied globally or on individual devices. Preventing Uninstallation will also prevent users from stopping the services of the agent.
Steps to uninstall the SmartEdge agent from Windows using uninstall key.
Steps to uninstall the SmartEdge agent from Mac device using uninstall key.
If Fail Open is checked, when both proxied and direct health checks fail over port 80 and 443, a new PAC file is set and user traffic will no longer be proxied.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE supports the ability to automatically push out selected version of SmartEdge agent to the devices.
At times when working with support, you might be asked to export the techsupport file for the SmartEdge agent. You can do this via commands for both macOS and Windows OS.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE will perform loopback exemptions automatically for Windows apps installed on the user's device.
From macOS Big Sur onwards, certificates are properly installed but they cannot be set to Always Trust by default. This will require you to locate the certificate and manually set it to Always Trust.
The macOS supported SmartEdge agent can be downloaded from the SmartEdge Proxy page in the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE portal.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE also supports the ability for admins to use an MDM or EMM to automatically install the SmartEdge agent on users MAC managed devices.
This Provides steps to install the SmartEdge Agent on multiple devices using GPO.
As the first step, you need to download the SmartEdge agent from the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE portal.
Download and open the install.bat file in a text editor and note the location, package, and key.

In the Tools menu, select Group Policy Management. In the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC), expand your Active Directory (AD) forest and domain and click the Group Policy Objects container. Right-click the Group Policy Objects container and select New from the menu. In the New GPO dialogue box, give the new Group Policy Object (GPO) a name and press OK. Open Server Manager using the icon on the desktop taskbar or from the Start screen. In the Tools menu, select Group Policy Management. In the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC), expand your Active Directory (AD) forest and domain and click the Group Policy Objects container. Right-click the Group Policy Objects container and select New from the menu. In the New GPO dialogue box, give the new Group Policy Object (GPO) a name and press OK. Open Server Manager using the icon on the desktop taskbar or from the Start screen. In the Tools menu, select Group Policy Management. In the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC), expand your Active Dir
This topic describes steps for adding the startup script settings to the GPO.
To apply a GPO policy for removing the agent, simply follow the same steps above but using uninstall.bat instead of install.bat.
Steps to roll out the SmartEdge agent to wider audience connected to VMWare Workspace for Windows.
Steps to roll out the SmartEdge agent to wider audience connected to VMWare Workspace for Windows.
Steps to deploy the SmartEdge agent to wider audience connected to JAMF Pro for macOS.
From macOS Big Sur onwards, user intervention is required to trust the certificate generated by the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE SmartEdge agent which is unique per device.
You can interoperate SmartEdge agent and F1A for managed app traffic and web traffic.
The Managed App traffic only mode is also known as CASB mode. In this mode, only managed applications’ traffic is proxied by SmartEdge Agent and all other traffic is proxied by F1A.
In the All HTTP/S Traffic mode, all traffic (managed app traffic and (SWG) web traffic) arrives first at SmartEdge Agent and is forwarded to F1A when required.

To interoperate the SmartEdge agent with F1A to monitor all web traffic (HTTPS), you should create a registry key use_f1e and set it to true, if one does not exist. This value will be read by seproxy on startup to indicate if the traffic must be forwarded to F1A.

Cloud SWG solution enables web traffic filtering when a SmartEdge agent cannot be deployed on the end user's machine, such as for Guest users or IoT devices or when the organization does not want to deploy an agent.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides you the ability to enforce Cloud SWG policies simply by forwarding traffic from known locations (branch offices) via GRE or IPsec tunnels configured between customer's edge device (Firewall or router) and data centers of Cloud SWG Transparent Proxy, without requiring a PAC or SmartEdge agent.

A Site represents a corporate location from which traffic will originate. While creating Site, you can configure either GRE or IPsec tunnel through which traffic should be sent over to cloud and create or add subnets groups within the site.

Once you create GRE and IPsec tunnels in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE, you need to configure GRE and IPsec tunnels on your edge devices so that web traffic originating from your internal subnets is forwarded to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Cloud via the configured tunnel successfully.
Within a company network, there will be multiple subnets. Each subnet will be assigned for a particular purpose, that is assigned to managed devices, IoT, guest, servers and so on.
After creating tunnels, you can monitor the status of each tunnel under Analyze > Tunnels page.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides you the ability to enforce Cloud SWG policies simply by forwarding traffic from known locations (branch offices) using the Host PAC file and a Certificate for SSL decryption, without requiring a SmartEdge agent.
A Site represents a corporate location from which traffic will originate.

You may get an error Software is Preventing Firefox from safely connecting to site while accessing websites on Mozilla Firefox if the user is enforced to authenticate using the domain's identity provider.
Forcepoint Mobile enables productivity via secure web access to corporate resources while protecting the user’s mobile device from web threats. It provides protection to iOS and iPadOS devices.

On the Protect > Forward Proxy > Settings page, you can set Cloud SWG Session Timeout, Cloud SWG Certificate Authority and Bypass Domains, Explicit Proxy PAC URLs and Bypass Domains, Host IPs or Subnets.
From the Cloud SWG Session Timeout drop-down, define how often users’ session should last before enforcing authentication.

You can select either Forcepoint Self Signed Certificate or an external CA, previously uploaded to Settings > Certificate , so that Cloud SWG can use those CA to generate dynamic certificates for websites visited.
Use the Explicit Proxy PAC URLs via HTTPS Port 443 to securely download the PAC file related to Cloud SWG Explicit Proxy over HTTPS.
If you are SWG only customer but not CASB and want to bypass Microsoft 365 domains when using the SmartEdge agent or Cloud SWG, then select the Bypass Microsoft 365 checkbox.
Bypass Domains, Host IPs or Subnets section allows you to enter specific domains, host IPs or subnets that you wish to not be proxied when using the SmartEdge agent or cloud SWG.
You can configure SWG Connection Policy, Cloud SWG Authentication Policy and SWG Content Policy to manage traffic through Cloud SWG and SmartEdge agent.

Before configuring any connection policies, it is important to review the Bypass and Exclusion Controls and Bypass Domains, Host IPs or Subnets for SmartEdge Agent and Bypass Domains, Host IPs or Subnets for Cloud SWG.

You can import SWG Connection policies in bulk by clicking the Import Policy (CSV) link available on the SWG Connection Policy tile. The Import Policy (CSV) link is available only when the ThreatSeeker URL Categories feature is enabled.

Admins can enforce the end user authentication by redirecting the user's session to the domain's identity provider. Once a user is authenticated, they are directed back to the proxy and appropriate policy is applied.

You can import Cloud SWG Authentication policies in bulk by clicking the Import Policy (CSV) link available on the Cloud SWG Authentication Policy tile. The Import Policy (CSV) link is available only when the ThreatSeeker URL Categories feature is enabled.

With the agent installed or Cloud SWG configured, admins can now configure web proxy policies to control and prevent users from accessing certain sites or domains that are untrustworthy or are possible points of data leakage.

You can import SWG Content policies in bulk by clicking the Import Policy (CSV) link available on the SWG Content Policy tile. The Import Policy (CSV) link is available only when the ThreatSeeker URL Categories feature is enabled.

The Device Profiling Proxy page will allow you to both configure the means to distinguish between a managed and an unmanaged device as well as implement a forward proxy deployment for applying inline policy actions.

Client Cert checking can be used to determine if a device is managed or unmanaged and enforce appropriate access control policies. A Root CA Certificate or chain of CA certificates is uploaded to validate if the client cert presented by a user during the SAML 2.0 authentication process is legitimate.

Certificates must be in the PEM format. Certificates must be installed in the User Personal Certificates folder on the machine. Browsers are run on a user basis and thus will check for certificates in ...
You can export to PEM from the Certificate dialog that is built into Windows. The export format is called Base-64 encoded X.509 (.CER) and that produces a valid PEM file with a .CER file extension.
You can convert any DER format cert to PEM running the following command and replacing the certificate filenames with your own:
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can support a cert chain but all intermediate certs need to be combined into one root CA file and uploaded to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.
The Forward Proxy Device Profiling Agent can be installed on Windows or Mac machines for a few different functions.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE's Agentless and Agent-based Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) provides an alternative to VPNs allowing admins to provide inline protection to internal apps without the need for VPN service to be running on the user's local machine.

Before installing ZTNA Connector on client server, you should create a custom location object with the external IP range of your office location or data center in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as this is needed during ZTNA connector installation.

After creating the custom location object, install the ZTNA connector using OVA Virtual Appliance or by using ZTNA Deployment Script. You can install the OVA Virtual Appliance within your server or you can install via a ZTNA Deployment Script.
This feature works via an OVA ZTNA connector that gets installed on your internal servers on the same network the internal apps that you want protected are located.
The ZTNA Deployment Script allows you to install the ZTNA connector when deploying an OVA Virtual Appliance on a VM is not an option.
Once you are done with installation the ZTNA package (either via OVA Virtual Appliance or the ZTNA Deployment Script), you will now need to run the ZTNA setup script for configuration.
All the installed and configured ZTNA connectors can be seen under Analyze > Connectors page.

After installing and configuring the ZTNA connector, you can add internal application or service to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE to provide contextual access controls to users via HTTP or HTTPS.

Once the installation and configuration of ZTNA connector is complete, you can add your internal apps to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE to enable contextual access controls and inline protection. Adding apps follows a similar setup to adding cloud-based apps, with the key difference being that you will select the Any HTTP/S ZTNA App/Service template.
You can access agentless ZTNA applications from the navigation bar or from the User portal.

After installing and configuring the ZTNA connector, you can add an internal application or service to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE for access over TCP (SSH, RDP, HTTP, HTTPS, SMB and SFTP) enabling contextual access controls for users.
Once the installation and configuration of the ZTNA is complete, you can now add your internal apps to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE to provide contextual access controls.

The end users can access the internal ZTNA TCP application either by using the IP address or by using the hostname by using a native application or a browser from a machine with SmartEdge agent installed.
Once Agent-based application is configured and saved, a default policy gets created under Policies page.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides Advanced Threat Protection (ATP) via partnerships with an antimalware provider.

You can protect your cloud application from malware by setting up ATP scanning using any of the ATP options that you have purchased. Setting up ATP scanning for your cloud application, is same as configuring any other data pattern with minor difference.
Describes the various types of file formats that are supported for scanning.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE supports inline DLP scanning, and API (Cloud) scanning.
Lists supported file MIME Types for both access and API scanning.
Lists additional file MIME Types supported specifically for API scanning.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE enterprise edition allows users to encrypt data at rest in cloud applications for both file and field level data. Keys can be managed in the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Keystore or customers can add their own KMIP Key Store to utilize existing key management appliance/servers (KMS or HSM).

When adding a key store to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE (that is, integration with a third party KMS or HSM), you can choose to authorize that integration in two different ways (authorize via ...
You may now generate derivative keys in the Key Vault to be used by Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE to encrypt data in applications.

The Email Normalization page is where you can add the domains of email addresses that are entered into fields within an app where you are performing Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE field tokenization and will help remove email address augmentations when aliases for a given email address are created.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides customers the ability to send files via ICAP (over TLS) to premise-based DLP systems.
Once you have enabled ICAP and configured the server settings, you can now adjust your DLP policy to forward to ICAP.

Customers must first enable the ICAP feature and configure the server settings before being able to send files to the DLP system. Steps Navigate to Protect > Integrations > ICAP and select Enabled ...

Since the ICAP server does not communicate directly with the source of data, but rather with the ICAP client, additional information may need to be passed from client to server to more completely identify a transaction.
Describes logs and alerts related to ICAP activities.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can integrate directly with Zscaler to send applications in Discovery ShadowIT reports to Zscaler for policy controls. This guide page will walk you through how to configure the integration with Zscaler.

Once you have setup your integration with Zscaler, you can now send applications from ShadowIT reports or found within Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE's cloud app database to Zscaler for control.
The IAM section contains the configuration pages used for maintaining your organization in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE (adding your domain, managing users/devices/etc).
You can configure user identity settings and synchronize user information from your directory in order to assign policies to users or groups.
Under the users card, you can manually add and manage users locally in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. You can also view their recent application activity.

You should create at least two administrator accounts, that is one for nominal tasks and the other as a backup, with System Administrator role or the custom administrator role which is equivalent to the one that you just created.
You can quickly add local users by entering their information manually or inviting users through email.
Admins can edit user details by selecting the users name to bring up the User Details dialog (for local users).
Users are assigned a risk score based on risky activities identified via API scans.
The User/Device Activity page displays the users activity over the past 7 days and can also show their activity baselined against groups they belong to.

You can provision as many email domains as you wish to add into the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE system. Every email domain that you wish to use within Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE must be configured, along with a corresponding authentication type for users logging in with email addresses in that domain.
Active Directory (AD) integration supports automatic provisioning and deprovisioning of users as well as synchronization of user group membership changes made in AD.

Synchronizing with Active Directory is a multi-step process which includes installing the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE AD Connector on a domain-joined Windows machine on your internal network.

When using SmartEdge Agent 2.4.0 or higher version with on-premises AD non-English users, whose device is linked to an on-premises AD domain, and if the AD Sync Agent is on a domain-joined Windows ...

IT organizations sometimes require a network proxy to be used in order to reach the internet from within the corporate network. Support for connecting to the portal through a proxy can be accomplished by simply modifying the agent's .NET configuration file.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE supports SCIM for provisioning users from Azure into Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.
As a first step, you should setup SCIM OAuth to generate access token in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.

You can setup the SCIM API integration with Okta so that admins can provision/deprovision users directly in Okta and have those users automatically created, attributes edited, or disabled within Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. You will need to create an OAuth connected app in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as well as a SCIM application inside of Okta.

Okta does not push over some user attributes that admins may want synced into Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. For these attributes (secondary email, mobile phone number, and manager), admins will need to add them to the SCIM app created in Okta and map them.
After creating an access token, you should create the SCIM application in Microsoft Entra ID. To learn more about using SCIM with Azure AD, refer to the Microsoft Guide.
When using SmartEdge Agent 2.4.0 or higher version with non-English users created directly in Entra ID and if those users' devices are linked to Entra ID domain, then SmartEdge Agent supports the ...

The Admin Roles page is where Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE admins can create different and unique admin roles to assign to users or groups. The role permissions can allow users to Edit, View, or Disabled (hidden) to each individual tab and the sub-component within the tab.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE comes with a default System Administrator role. The System Administrator role has full rights to the portal.
Users can be assigned a single admin role either individually (applied on the user's profile) or via group membership.
Admins can assign admin roles to users on their individual profiles from the Users and Groups page.
Admins can assign admin role membership to groups which users can inherit by being members of those groups.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE does not support users being assigned to more than one admin role. You will see red errors if there is a conflict when a user is assigned to more than one group with different admin roles.

At the bottom of the Admin Roles page, you will see a field to configure the max session timeout. This control will set the maximum time allowed for a session before timing out for both admins and users if no timeout policies have been configured.
You can configure various applications to support Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML Service Provider.
This section describes how to configure ACS Proxy in Microsoft 365, Microsoft Entra ID and Okta.
You can setup an ACS Proxy working with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE, PingFed, and Microsoft365 using Active Directory 2019 as the directory store.
Once you have setup all 3 configurations in PingFed and verified that your connections are successful, then you can connect PingFed to M365.

To setup an ACS Proxy working with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE, PingFed, and 0365 using Active Directory 2019 as the directory store, you need to create Data Store, Password Credential Validator and Active Directory Domains/Kerberos Realms.

You can integrate PingFed with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. You will need to create an SP connection in PingFed to add Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE and also need to add an IdP object inside of Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE for PingFed. It is best to have two windows open logged into PingFed and Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE for this setup.
Use the provided Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE Python script which calls the Okta API to setup the ACS Proxy.
You can configure Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) to support Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML Service Provider.
You can configure Okta to support Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML Service Provider. Admin can use the registered application available in Okta for easy configuration.

You can configure Okta to support Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML Service Provider. You should add Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as an application inside of Okta and then configure Okta as the external IdP inside of Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.

You can configure Okta to support custom Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML Service Provider. If Okta is not the first IdP you are configuring in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE, you should create custom Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as an application inside of Okta and then configure Okta as the external IdP inside of Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.
You can configure PingOne as an external IdP inside of Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.

You can configure Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML SP for DUO. DUO typically provides both, two factor authentication and Identity Provider (IdP) services. Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can point to any IdP for user authentication and account creation.

When configuring the global session policies, Admins can enforce two-factor authentication (MFA) for admins and users when logging into any application or as part of a policy action when suspicious login behavior is detected.
You can setup OneLogin as an IdP in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE for authentication.

You can add Cyberark Idaptive as an external IdP via SAML SSO integration with Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE offers both IdP-initiated SAML SSO (for SSO access through the user portal or Idaptive mobile applications) and SP-initiated SAML SSO (for SSO access directly through the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE web application). You can configure Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE for either or both types of SSO. Enabling both methods ensures that users can log into Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE in different situations such as clicking through a notification email. Refer to the Cyberark's documentation for more information.
You can add PingFederate to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a third party IdP.
You can set up Microsoft Entra ID as an IdP within Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE. This setup will work to configure SAML SSO proxy authentication with any apps outside of Microsoft apps.
Use the configuration information to register Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE as a SAML SP on other external SAML IdP.
Use the additional information that may be needed during your IdP setup that is not covered in the primary setups, such as Default Relay State.

You can configure your IdP to send Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE the following attributes with the SAML assertion so that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE receives the necessary user information.
You can configure Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE on a per application basis to send additional attributes with the SAML assertion sent to the protected cloud application.

When configuring the global login policies, Admins can enforce two-factor authentication (MFA) for admins and users when logging into any application or as part of a policy action when suspicious login behavior is detected.
When security question is used with MFA enabled, users will be prompted upon their first login (after the setting change) to pick 3 possible questions and provide answers.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE provides an option to use any Authenticator app with verification code for MFA: including Google Authenticator, Okta-Verify, Microsoft Authenticator, etc.
To enable DUO Security (Push) for use in MFA in Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE, you will need to configure an API connection between Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE and DUO.
The Settings section contains the majority of your setting configurations to be used in policies or integrations.

If Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE is being used as the IdP (as in users will land on a Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE log in page to authenticate to their apps) you have the option to customize the UI of the login page.
Rest APIs enable you to programmatically access data and configuration from your Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE instance.
Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE' Configuration REST API supports creating users and groups programmatically for integration into external user management, governance, or scripted solutions.
You can programmatically manage users via REST APIs.
You can programmatically manage groups via REST APIs.
As an Administrator, you can choose to authorize by sending a username and password with every request or can choose to setup OAuth for authentication.
As an Administrator, you can choose to authorize by sending a username and password with every request for authentication.

Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE supports OAuth 2.0 for REST API authentication. Admins can setup a config API for user/group provisioning via a SCIM or Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE API, a log export API, or an IP API to pull Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE IP addresses for firewall or proxy configurations.

Admin can delete OAuth setup whenever the application authentication via OAuth is no longer required. If you delete the OAuth setup for the application, all the users and groups associated with the OAuth application will be deleted.
The Certificates page allows you to generate a Certificate Signing Request (CSR), upload a Certificate Authority (CA), or a server certificate and private key.

You can create a CSR that you download and get signed by your CA to re-upload to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE to establish a 2-way TLS connection between Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE and a callout endpoint.

In order to authenticate a connection from a cloud app, you will need to upload a Certificate Authority (CA) for authentication. The primary use case is uploading a CA to Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE that will be used to authenticate the app during the 2-way TLS handshake between Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE and the application.

Modern Android and iOS devices now require HTTPS autodiscovery for automatic configuration of the mail server. If you are planning to use Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE for mobile device protection and enable mobile cutoff, you will need to upload a server certificate and private key for your email domain so that Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE can properly autodiscover your domain when configuring the server information on the mobile device.
The Support section contains links to Admin guide, URL Lookup page, and Forcepoint Customer Hub.

Use the inbuilt tool to review the category of a URL or IP entered. This is helpful in finding equivalent ThreatSeeker URL Categories, Enterprise App Categories, Web Browsing Categories along with their respective reputation scores for the entered URL or IP.
The admin guide is your resource for learning how to setup and deploy Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | SSE.

https://help.forcepoint.com/fpone/insigh.summary: Insights is a centralized reporting and analytics service that is hosted within the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud.
You can access Insights from your SSE or Forcepoint RBI.
Insights provides four pre-defined dashboards to provide insights across Forcepoint products.
The Summary dashboard is the landing dashboard when you access Insights from SSE.
The Forcepoint Security Index (FSI) is a metric specifically designed to evaluate the implementation and deployment of Forcepoint products within an organization's network.
Web score measures if the recommended configurations and policies with respect to the SWG capabilities in SSE are implemented.
CASB Inline score evaluates the implementation of the best practices for the four pillars of CASB.
You can update the FSI score based on your SSE deployments.
The Active Agents score is a ratio of the number of unique monthly SmartEdge Agent check-ins seen to the number of licensed users purchased.
The Logins score is a ratio of the number of unique monthly user-logins seen by SSE to the number of licensed users purchased.
The API Scanning score evaluates the implementation of the following best practices for API Scanning for up to three applications added by the customer in SSE.

The Economic Value allows you to understand the potential return on investment for your use of Forcepoint ONE. To use this effectively you should tailor the calculation for your Industry and your use of Forcepoint ONE.
To use the Economic Value effectively Forcepoint recommends that you consider each aspect and adjust it accordingly for your Industry, your use of Forcepoint ONE, and personal perspective.
Use the Data Security dashboard for an overview of your use of Forcepoint ONE to secure and protect your data across your licensed channels—API, CASB Inline and Web.
Use the Threat Protection dashboard for an overview of your cloud usage across your licensed channels—API, CASB Inline and Web.
Use the Remote Browser Isolation dashboard to view the RBI product visibility along with summary of browsing, file download and upload summary and reporting.
The Browse Activity Summary widget displays cumulative browsing activity and related security events per user for the selected period.

The Security Threat Summary widget displays information for all browsed sites where the threat score exceeded the allowable level set by the administrator for the selected period. Refer to Adding a Policy Rule to set the allowable threat score.
The Download Summary and Upload Summary widgets lists all file that were either downloaded and uploaded respectively by the users.
You can view the log reports in the Remote Browser Isolation dashboard.
You can export any of the pre-defined dashboard as a PDF file.
The Catalog page enables you to create and manage custom widgets and custom dashboards as per your organization's requirements.
The Dashboards tab on the Catalog page displays all the custom dashboards and dashboard groups that you have previously created. By default, the Dashboards tab is selected.
You can filter dashboards and dashboard groups in the Dashboards tab using the filter option. Filters are supported for the name, tags, publisher, and schedules columns.
You can view the dashboard details from the Dashboards tab of the Catalog page.
You can create a custom dashboard as per your organization's need.
While creating or modifying a custom dashboard, you can add or change widgets.
You can modify the existing custom dashboards when needed.
While creating or modifying the dashboard, you can add a maximum of five filters in the dashboard to filter all the widgets in the dashboard.

While modifying the dashboard, you can configure advanced options, such as disabling report view and enabling drilldown capability of the widget in the dashboard. The report view enables the ability to navigate from the Dashboard to the corresponding report view for a selected Widget.
You can create a new copy of an existing dashboard while modifying it.
You can delete the custom dashboard while viewing it, if it is no longer needed.

You can group existing dashboards into a dashboard group. This is a dashboard that presents all grouped dashboards on a single page with a tab menu used to allow quick navigation between each individual dashboard. It allows the Dashboard Designer to group related dashboards.
You can create a new copy of an existing dashboard group while modifying it.
You can export any of the dashboard or dashboard group as a PDF file.
You can delete the existing dashboard group while viewing it when no longer needed.

You can modify the dashboard group when needed. Steps On the left pane, click the icon. The Catalog page opens displaying the Dashboards tab details. To expand the Global folder and view the sub-folders, click the expand icon. Navigate to appropriate sub-folder by expanding the sub-folders. To view the dashboards included in the group, identify the dashboard group and click on it. The dashboard group opens in view mode. To edit the dashboard group, click Edit. In the Collection Name, change the dashboard group name. In the Description field, modify the description of the dashboard. Assign the dashboard group to a folder. For more information, refer to Assigning a dashboard or widget to the folder. In the Tags field, enter any tags associated with the dashboard group. You need to add at least one tag. To pin the dashboard group, toggle the Pin Collection to Enabled. By default, the Pin Collection is set to Disabled. On the Included Dashboards section: Enter text in the Search field to filter dashboards based on the text. Select all the required dashboards that need to be part of dashboard group. You can add a maximum of six dashboards. Click + to move selected dashboards from the Select Dashboards section to the Applied to this collection (arrangement defines order) section. All the dashboards in the Applied to this collection (arrangement defines order) section appear as tabs in the same sequence as is in the Applied to this collection (arrangement defines order) section at t
You can delete custom dashboard(s) and dashboard group(s) that are no longer needed.
The Widgets tab on the Catalog page displays widgets that your admins have previously created under the Global folder.
You can filter widgets in the Widgets tab using the filter option. Filters are supported for the name, collection name, product, tags, publisher, linked dashboards, and schedules columns.
Use the Discover page to query data and create your own widgets, which you can then add to your custom dashboards or use as standalone reports.
You can create widgets under the Discover page and use those widgets as standalone reports or while configuring custom dashboards.
You can select a data source for your widget from the available data collections in Insights.
While creating or modifying the widget in the Discover page, you can select the desired dimensions and measures to view data of your selected data source in a widget.
Based on the dimensions and measures selected, you can select one of the available chart types from the Chart section to visualize the data.
You can add filters to display data based on certain parameters in the widget.
You can filter and view the detailed data of the selected data source in pivot chart. You can also filter data using the advanced filter option available in the All Data section of Pivot table view.
You can modify the details of an existing widget using the Edit option in the Discover page to update the widget or save it as a new widget.

You can export any of the widget as a PDF file. Steps On the left pane, click the icon. The Catalog page opens displaying the Dashboards tab details. To view the widgets, click the Widget tab. Navigate to appropriate sub-folder by expanding the Global folder. To view the widget details, click the widget report. The Discover page opens displaying widgets details (name, description, dimensions, measures, filters, and sorting applied on the widget) in view only mode. Adjust the report time frame for your widget. Click the time filter. The dialog opens. To filter logs based on selected Time period, select one of the following: Last Hour Last 24 Hours 7 Days 14 Days 30 Days 45 Days 60 Days Custom Range If you have selected the Custom Range option, then: To select a From date for your transaction view, enter a date or select the date from the calendar and then click the time icon to select the time range. To select a To date for your transaction view, enter a date or select the date from the calendar and then click the time icon to select the time range. Note: The date and time formats are the same as those configured on your system. To save the changes, click Apply. On the upper-right corner of the widget, click the icon. The preview of widget opens displaying the name, selected time frame for which widget was generated, and report generated date and time. Note: If you are exporting a widget, the description appears in the preview if the option to display description in the PDF ex
You can export definitions of widget catalog in the JSON file. You can modify the exported JSON file to create a new catalog report and import it to the Widgets tab.
Import the JSON file to the Widgets tab of the Catalog page to create or to modify existing widget reports in bulk.
Delete all the existing custom widget(s) if no longer needed.
in the Dashboards tab and the Widgets tab of the Catalog page helps you in grouping custom dashboards and widgets.
You can create sub-folders within the Global folder of the Dashboards tab and the Widgets tab in the Catalog page to organize your dashboards and widgets within the specific sub-folders.
While creating or updating the dashboard, dashboard group or widget, you can assign it to a new or existing folder under the Global folder.
You can rename sub-folders within the Global folder.
You can delete a sub-folder that is no longer needed and does not want to be displayed.
Use the Scheduler page to view and manage the schedules set for sending reports of custom or pre-defined dashboards, dashboard groups, or widgets.
You can create schedules for sending reports of dashboards, dashboard groups, or widgets to specific email addresses.
You can choose the name, subject, and any other information to be displayed in the scheduled mail.
You can choose the frequency, time, and the start and end dates for your schedule.
You can choose the email recipients for your schedule.
You can send dashboards, dashboard groups, and widgets as attachments in your schedule.
You can update the existing schedules from your Scheduler.
You can delete the existing schedules in your Scheduler.

For your convenience, Web Security includes predefined data security content classifiers to detect and report on data loss in your organization and help you conform to industry regulations in your geo-location. Predefined classifiers enable you to quickly and easily define what type of content is considered a security breach on your network. Many policies are disabled by default, but you can enable them in the cloud portal by navigating to the Data Security tab of your web policy. You can also create custom data security classifiers on the Policy Management > Content Classifiers page. The predefined classifiers included in the cloud service are constantly being updated and improved. There are several types of policies: Type Description Personally Identifiable Information (PII) Policies for detecting personally identifiable information such as social security, passport, and drivers’ license numbers. The rules that are enforced depend on the region you selected. Protected Health Information (PHI) Policies for detecting personal health information such as disease names and medications. The rules that are enforced depend on the region you selected. Payment Card Industry (PCI) Policies for detecting credit card numbers and cardholder data. The rules that are enforced depend on the region you selected. Data Theft Policies for detecting various attempts to steal sensitive data. Regular expressions (RegEx) are a powerful way of matching a sequence of simple characters. You can use regular expressions in Forcepoint Email Security Cloud to create dictionary entries for lexical rules (see Filtering using lexical rules). You can enclose a range of characters in square brackets to match against all of those characters. For example: Expression Description [ ] may also be used on a range of characters separated by a – character. [0-9] matches any digit. [a-z] matches any alpha character [a-z0-9] matches any alphanumeric character ^ is the “not” character, so [^0-9] matches against any character that is not a digit. Although you can use ranges to specify a group of characters, you can also use the following shortcuts: Expression Description . matches against any character \d matches against a digit [0-9] \D matches against a non-digit [^0-9] \s matches against a whitespace character (such as a tab, space, or line feed character) \S matches against a non-whitespace character \w matches against an alphanumeric character [a-zA-Z_0-9] \W matches against a non-alphanumeric character \xhh matches against a control character (for the hexadecimal character hh) \uhhhh matches against a Unicode character (for the hexadecimal character hhhh) Note: As the backslash character is used to denote a specific search expression, if you want to match against this character, you must enter a double backslash (\\). Profiles Profiles are a set of attributes that define the endpoint agent behavior. The Default profile can be configured by each tenant to support its specific needs. Profiles can also be used to set different behavior for different segments in the same tenant. The Profile tab on the Endpoint management dashboard provides options for defining profiles for each tenant to support specific needs. 1 Name: Each profile entry is stored using the specified name. 2 Applies to: Specifies the endpoint or the organization unit to which the profile applies. 3 OS type: Specifies whether the operating system running on the endpoint machine is Windows or macOS. 4 OTA Windows: Displays the version of the agent running on Windows endpoint machine. 5 OTA macOS: Displays the version of the agent running on macOS endpoint machine. 6 Status: Indicates whether the profile is enabled or disabled. 7 Reorder: For a tenant there can be more than one profile created. The order of the profile sets its priority. C

Prerequisites Pre-requisites for installing the agent. Note: Before installing the agent, ensure your AV/EDR policies allow the installer and agent runtime to run and create outbound connections. Introduction Introduction

About the Forcepoint DSE Agent The Forcepoint DSE Agent is a modernized evolution of the Forcepoint F1E. It is built from the same underlying codebase as F1E but delivered as a dedicated branch that incorporates updated components and platform improvements. Throughout this document, the general term “Forcepoint Agent” is used to refer to this endpoint version. About the Forcepoint DSE Agent The Forcepoint DSE Agent is a modernized evolution of the Forcepoint F1E. It is built from the same underlying codebase as F1E but delivered as a dedicated branch that incorporates updated components and platform improvements. Throughout this document, the general term “Forcepoint Agent” is used to refer to this endpoint version.

About the agent for Forcepoint Cloud Security Gateway The agent combines the capability of the classic Forcepoint F1E agent's Proxy Connect Endpoint and Direct Connect Endpoint in one package. The agent can intelligently switch between the proxy connect and direct modes depending on network conditions and performance. The classic Proxy Connect Endpoint and Direct Connect Endpoint agents provide security and monitoring of web activities, but you can install only one of the agents on a single endpoint. With this new agent, you have both proxy connect and direct connect modes installed and available on a single endpoint machine and also intelligently switch between the two modes. About the agent for Forcepoint Cloud Security Gateway The agent combines the capability of the classic Forcepoint F1E agent's Proxy Connect Endpoint and Direct Connect Endpoint in one package. The agent can intelligently switch between the proxy connect and direct modes depending on network conditions and perform

Endpoint management Endpoint management enables organizations to centrally manage all their related endpoints from one web console by streamlining management and ensuring consistent security throughout the organization. Administrators can easily deploy and manage endpoint software versions, settings, and security policies across all endpoints, and gain granular visibility into endpoint activity, including deployment status, release versions, and usage statistics. The agent supports following services: Data Protection (DLP) Web Security both Proxy Connect (PCEP) and Direct Connect (DCEP) Device Control User Activity Monitoring Access to the individual services is dependent on your Forcepoint product license(s). Updating the agent manually Updating the agent manually allows administrators to update the agent to a specific version of the agent as per required schedule. When you manually update an agent to the latest version, you download the latest agent from the management portal, then deploy it to your managed endpoints. The below procedure provides a high-level overview of the update steps. The full installation procedure is provided in the installation sections section of this document. Steps Download the agent from the management portal. Either manually install the agent or deploy the agent using your preferred deployment tool (such as Intune or Jamf). For more information, see the installing the agent section of this document. Note: You do not need to uninstall the earlier version of the agent before installing the latest version of the agent on your endpoints. Agent status information is available as soon as agent installation begins on the endpoint machine. Migrating from Forcepoint F1E to the Forcepoint agent To know on agent support for on-prem DLP subset of use cases, contact Forcepoint customer support to see if this is suitable for you. If you have previously deploy classic F1E Proxy Connect Endpoint and Direct Connect Endpoint agents in your organization, you can migrate to the Forcepoint agent easily. With the classic Forcepoint F1E agents, you could only configure one of the agent operating modes on a single endpoint out of proxy connect and direct connect. With the new agent, you can have both proxy connect and direct connect modes installed and available on the same endpoint and the new agent also supports auto-switching. To migrate your endpoints from the classic Forcepoint F1E to new agent, you need to uninstall Forcepoint F1E, then install the new agent. Migrate from Forcepoint F1E to the new agent This procedure outlines the high-level steps needed to migrate from the classic Forcepoint F1E agents (Proxy Connect Endpoint and Direct Connect Endpoint) to the new agent. Forcepoint Cloud Security Gateway customers can download the new agent from the Forcepoint Cloud Security Gateway portal and do not need a Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | DLP license to download and configure the agent. Steps Download the installer package from the Forcepoint Cloud Security Gateway portal. Remove the Forcepoint F1E agents from the endpoints that were previously installed. Note: If you have other Forcepoint F1E agents installed, such as Forcepoint DLP Endpoint, they will be removed. You will need to reinstall those agents. Restart the endpoint. Deploy the new agent to your endpoints. Configure the new agent mode in the Forcepoint Cloud Security Gateway portal or the Forcepoint Data Security Cloud | DLP as per your available licenses. https://help.forcepoint.com/fponefirewal.summary: Introduction Forcepoint ONE Firewall is a cloud-based firewall capability for all ports and protocols whose communication is initiated in the outbound (site or device to Internet) direction. It includes granular firewall policies, malware detection, Layer 7 Deep Packet Inspection (DPI), and an industry-leading Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) and threat protection service. Forcepoint ONE Firewall can secure remote branch office sites with better scale than branch firewalls, and reduced capital costs. It can apply consistent security policies across all users and locations using a flexible and centralized policy management. Also, it provides excellent visibility and control over networks across all sites without deploying physical appliances. User Authentication for Forcepoint ONE Firewall Users are authenticated by the Cloud SWG component of Forcepoint ONE. To authenticate for Forcepoint ONE Firewall, the user needs to make a web request, during which they are displayed with the Force

Logs The Logs page displays detailed log information for the information displayed on the Dashboard summary page. The selected filters and time period is carried over from the Dashboard page to the Logs page. Note: If you click the View Logs button in the Dashboard page, then only the selected filters are applied to the Logs page. If you use the Navigation pane to navigate to the Logs page, the filter is removed. In the Logs page, you can only view 10000 log entries. You must export the logs to view the complete log entries for the last 30 days. For more details about exporting logs, refer to the Log Export and the AWS Access Key and Secret Key topics. For more information on how to use Filters and Time period drop-down menu, refer to the Dashboard filters and Time period drop-down menu topics, in the Forcepoint ONE | Firewall online help documentation. Dashboard The Dashboard displays a summary of firewall activity for a time period. If you use the Navigation pane to navigate to the Logs page, the filter is removed. Use the time period drop-down menu to change the reporting period to the last 24 hours, 7 days, or 30 days. By default, data is displayed for all traffic, for the past 1 hour. Click View Logs to view detailed log information for the information that is displayed in the Dashboard. Table 1. Summary panels Panel Description Users Displays the total number of active users. Sites Displays the total number of active sites or hosting locations. Dashboard filters You can use the Filter to customize the data that is displayed on the Dashboard or Logs page. Click the Filter button. The Filter By panel is displayed. Type or click in one or more fields in the Filter By panel to select the information by which to filter the dashboard data. Click Apply to apply the filter or Cancel to discard the changes. Note: To remove individual filters, click x on the filter element that is displayed at the top of the dashboard, or to remove all filters, click Clear all.
